'''''Stropharia caerulea''''', [[common name|commonly]] known as the '''blue roundhead''', is an inedible species of [[agaric]] fungus in the family [[Strophariaceae]]. It is a common species found in Europe and North America, where it grows as a [[saprophyte]] in meadows, roadsides, hedgerows, gardens, and woodchip mulch. ''S. caerulea'' was officially [[species description|described]] to science in 1979, although it was known to be a distinct species for about two centuries before that. The [[taxon]] ''Stropharia cyanea'', as defined by [[Risto Tuomikoski]] in 1953, and used by several later authors, is a [[synonym (biology)|synonym]] of ''S. caerulea''.

The [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] ([[mushroom]]s) of ''Stropharia caerulea'' feature a greenish-blue [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] sparsely covered in white flecks of [[partial veil|veil]] at the margin, and a sticky, glutinous surface texture. [[Lamella (mycology)|Gills]] on the cap underside have an adnate or sinuate attachment to the [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]]. They are initially pale purplish-brown, becoming darker brown in age as the spores mature. The greenish stipe is covered in white scales up to a thin, transient [[annulus (mycology)|ring]]. It is similar in appearance to its less common relative ''[[Stropharia aeruginosa]]'', but that species has a more robust ring on its stipe, more scales on the cap, and darker gills with white edges.

==Taxonomy==
In 1953, the Finnish scientist [[Risto Tuomikoski]] observed that the well-known ''[[Stropharia aeruginosa]]'' had a lookalike species that was characterized by a brown [[spore print]], an indistinct, temporary ring on the [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]], and chrysocystidia{{#tag:ref|Chrysocystidia are [[cystidia]] whose contents contain a yellow [[cytoplasmic inclusion|inclusion]] that becomes more deeply yellow when exposed to [[ammonia]] or other alkaline compounds. They are characteristic of the genus ''[[Stropharia]]''.<ref name="Ulloa 2014"/>|group=nb}} lining the gill edges. Tuomikoski called this lookalike ''Stropharia cyanea'', a name he based on [[James Bolton]]'s 1820 taxon ''Agaricus cyaneus''. Later researchers confirmed the existence and widespread European distribution of this [[taxon]]. Tuomikoski's use of the name ''S. cyanea'', however, was incorrect as Bolton's type refers to the purple-brown spored species ''S. aeruginosa''.<ref name="Kreisel 1979"/> Despite this, the misapplied name ''S. cyanea'' has persisted in some contemporary [[field guide]]s.<ref name="Bas 1999"/>{{#tag:ref|Examples include ''Mushrooms'' by Thomas Laessoe (2002),<ref name="Laessoe 2002"/> and ''Mushrooms and Other Fungi'' by Roger Phillips (2013).<ref name="Phillips 2013"/>|group=nb}}

''Stropharia caerulea'' was first mentioned in the scientific literature by James Bolton in 1788, under the name ''Agaricus politus''. This usage is not considered [[validly published name (botany)|valid]] according to [[International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants|nomenclatural rules]], because it was used by [[Christian Hendrik Persoon]] to refer to [[Entoloma politum|another species]] in his 1801 ''Synopsis methodica fungorum'', which is a [[sanctioned name|sanctioned]] work.<ref name="urlFungorum: Agaricus politus"/> ''Stropharia caerulea'' was officially [[species description|described]] by mycologist [[Hanns Kreisel]] in 1979 from collections made near [[Woldegk]], Germany.<ref name="Kreisel 1979"/> [[Machiel Noordeloos]] transferred the species to ''[[Psilocybe]]'' in 1995,<ref name="Noordeloos 1995"/> but today this genus is mostly reserved for species that contain the [[psychoactive]] compounds [[psilocybin]] and [[psilocin]].<ref name="Norvell 2010"/> Although psilocybin had once been reported from ''S. caerulea'',<ref name="Margot 1981"/> subsequent analyses have not revealed any traces of the substance in the fruit bodies.<ref name="Bresinsky 1990"/>

The [[botanical name|specific epithet]] ''caerulea'' is [[Latin]] for "blue". The mushroom is [[common name|commonly]] known as the blue roundhead.<ref name="BMS"/> French mycologist Régis Courtecuisse has called the mushroom "verdigris agaric",<ref name="Courtecuisse 1999"/> but numerous other authors use this name to refer instead to ''Stropharia aeruginosa''.<ref name="Phillips 2013"/><ref name="Roberts 2011"/><ref name="Jordan 2015"/><ref name="Stevenson 2010"/>

==Description==
[[File:Psilocybe caerulea a1 (1).JPG|thumb|left|A prominent characteristic is the smooth and scaly surface upper and lower stipe texture, divided by a short-lived annular zone.]]
Fruitbodies have conical to flattened caps measuring {{convert|2|–|7.5|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} in diameter. They usually have a low, broad [[umbo (mycology)|umbo]]. The colour of the cap depends on its age, ranging from pale blue-green to yellowish-bluish green. There is often a whitish zone around the margin, which invariably has bluish-green tints. When moist, the cap is sticky with a [[cap cuticle|cuticle]] that may be readily peeled; dry caps are smooth and shiny. Gills are initially pale purplish-brown, becoming darker brown in age as the spores mature. They have an [[adnation|adnate]] or [[wikt:sinuate|sinuate]] attachment to the [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]]. The stipe has a short-lived [[annulus (mycology)|annular]] (ring) zone; above this zone the stipe is smooth, while below it is fibrous and scaly. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is colourless, although it may have tinges of blue in the cap and stipe, and lacks any distinctive odour or flavour.<ref name="Bas 1999"/> ''Stropharia cyanea'' fruit bodies are not [[edible mushroom|edible]].<ref name="Phillips 2013"/>

The [[spore print]] is brown.<ref name="Kreisel 1979"/>{{#tag:ref|In his 1979 publication, Kreisel explicitly notes the lack of purple tones in the brown spore print colour, which he states is "a unique characteristic in the genus ''Stropharia''".<ref name="Kreisel 1979"/> However, this feature is de-emphasized by some later authors, who give the spore print colour as purple-brown.<ref name="Bas 1999"/><ref name="Laessoe 2002"/><ref name="Courtecuisse 1999"/>|group=nb}} [[Basidiospore|Spores]] typically measure 8.0–9.0 by 4.0–5.5 [[micrometre|µm]], and have an [[ellipsoid]] to oblong to ovoid shape, depending on the viewing angle. [[Basidia]] (spore-bearing cells) are narrowly club-shaped, four-spored, and have dimensions of 24–40 by 7–12 µm. The cheilochrysocystidia (found on the gill edge) are club-shaped, measuring 30–55 by 4–40 µm, with a neck that is 2–5 µm wide. Pleurochrysocystidia (on the gill face) are 40–60 by 5–18 µm with a 2–4 µm-wide neck. [[Clamp connection]]s are abundant in all tissues of ''S. caerulea''.<ref name="Bas 1999"/> The fungus produces [[acanthocyte]]s, which are spiny cells produced on short branches on the mycelium.<ref name="Farr 1980"/>

===Similar species===
[[File:Límcovka měděnková.JPG|thumb|right|The lookalike ''S. aeruginosa'' has white scales around its cap margin.]]
There are a few greenish ''Stropharia'' with which ''S. caerulea'' might be confused. ''[[Stropharia pseudocyanea]]'' is an uncommon species that grows in meadows. It has a more slender form than ''S. caerulea'', a soft, spongy stipe, and flesh with an odour similar to fresh pepper. Microscopically, it has a dense palisade of slender, capitate (with a spherical tip) non-staining cheilocystidia on the gill edge.<ref name="Henrici 2002"/> This gives the gills of young, fresh fruit bodies a whitish edge, a feature that is absent from ''S. caerulea''. Another lookalike, ''[[Stropharia aeruginosa|S. aeruginosa]]'', is less common than ''S. caerulea''. It is distinguished from the latter by the well-developed ring zone on its stipe, darker gills with white edges, and more numerous whitish scales around the cap margin.<ref name="Henrici 2002"/><ref name="Kibby 2010"/> Additionally, ''S. aeruginosa'' has more stable colours than ''S. caerulea'', the colouration of which tends to quickly wash out. However, collections of ''Stropharia'' often show characteristics that are intermediate between two or more species, making them difficult to identify accurately.<ref name="Trudell 2009"/>

==Habitat, distribution, and ecology==
''Stropharia caerulea'' is a [[saprophytic]] fungus that fruits singly or in groups.<ref name="MushroomExpert"/> It grows in or on meadows, roadsides, [[hedgerow]]s, gardens, and [[woodchips|woodchip]] mulch.<ref name="Kibby 2010"/> In Europe it is often found in [[beech]] woods in [[soil pH|alkaline soil]].<ref name="Laessoe 2002"/> It is a common species found throughout Europe, where it fruits from July to November.<ref name="Bas 1999"/> Although also found in North America, generally fruiting from August to October,<ref name="Phillips 2013"/> the full extent of its distribution there is unknown.<ref name="MushroomExpert"/>

Fruitbodies of ''Stropharia caerulea'' form [[mycelial cord]]s–rootlike structures consisting of a dense mass of hyphae–which create extensive underground networks that move nutrients and allow the fungus to "forage" for resources. These cords are often associated with stems and [[rhizome]]s of the [[common nettle]] (''Urtica dioica'').<ref name="Donnelly 1997"/> These mycelial systems' development and the species's interactions with other cord-forming wood decomposer basidiomycetes have been investigated. The mycelia of ''Stropharia caerulea'' form a [[fractal]] structure characterized by a dense, relatively slowly extending front, a formation associated with finding relatively homogeneously distributed nutrients–equivalent to short-range foraging. An increase in the supply of soil [[nitrogen]] or [[phosphorus]] increases the fractal branching of the mycelia, allowing increased uptake of nutrients.<ref name="Donnelly 1997b"/><ref name="Donnelly 1998"/><ref name="Donnelly 2001"/>
